title: 106_hr2079
content:
The Act titled the "Terry Peak Land Transfer Act of 1999" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 outlines the findings and purposes of the Act. Congress finds that a portion of the National Forest System land in the Black Hills National Forest is currently permitted to the Terry Peak Ski Area. This land makes up only 10% of the Ski Area, with the remaining 90% being privately owned. Due to the land being encumbered by ski facilities and privately owned improvements, Congress believes it serves little purpose in public ownership and should be transferred to the Ski Area to streamline land management and reduce administrative costs. The Ski Area is interested in acquiring land from the United States to eliminate administrative costs. The Black Hills National Forest has small private inholdings complicating land management, which can be acquired by the United States with funding. Proceeds from the Terry Peak conveyance can fund the acquisition of inholdings in the National Forest. The Ski Area wants to acquire National Forest System land at Terry Peak to eliminate administrative costs. Proceeds from the conveyance will be used to acquire more desirable lands for permanent public use in the Black Hills National Forest. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS.

(1) The term ``Secretary'' refers to the Secretary of Agriculture.
(2) The term ``selected land'' is approximately 41.42 acres depicted as Government lots 6 and 11, section 2, township 4 north, range 2 east, Black Hills meridian.
(3) The terms ``Terry Peak Ski Area'' and ``Ski Area'' refer to the Black Hills Chairlift Company or its successors.

SEC. 4. LAND CONVEYANCE AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS. The Secretary of Agriculture will convey approximately 41.42 acres of selected land to Terry Peak Ski Area at fair market value. The value of the land will be determined using nationally recognized appraisal standards, with costs covered by the Ski Area. The conveyance should be completed within 6 months of the enactment of the Act, unless mutually agreed upon otherwise. Pre-disposal analyses must be completed before the land is conveyed. The Secretary must complete pre-disposal analyses and clearances for various environmental factors. Proceeds received will be used to acquire replacement land for the Black Hills National Forest in South Dakota. The acquired lands will be added to the forest and may involve boundary modifications. The Secretary has the authority to adjust Forest boundaries under the Weeks Act. The conveyance to the Ski Area is subject to existing rights and easements on the selected land.
